Posts.Content: Lavender250 wrote: I'm having a palpation-guided core needle biopsy on 9/2. There's no corresponding imaging for this lump so she's doing this all by hand. She warned that there's a chance for sampling error (great). I was just wondering a few things. - Is core needle a normal recommendation for a palpable lump that is rather big? I'm just thinking into the future here. If it's cancer, obviously they will take those steps. But if it's not, are they just gonna leave a somewhat large lump in my breast? I'm just wondering what this could mean. It sounds like many women have excisional. It was offered as an option but my BS recommended core needle. - Is it true that core needles can spread cancer cells if the lump is malignant? I can't find exact studies.  -What does it feel like? What is recovery like? How bad does the needle hurt going into an already painful lump? Can my husband be with me? -How common is it to have inconclusive results that require more testing or biopsies? I want answers this time! I just got my second ultrasound bill and my heart stopped. I'll be insured soon but still. Is there anything I should know about this procedure? I appreciate it! I plan on asking questions in the office but I want to make sure that this is the right choice for me. I don't want to have to come back for another test if excisional is more accurate. I'll need to change this soon if I decide excisional is best. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Preparing for biopsy Lavender250 Gottobme

Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2011 04:10AM Lavender250 wrote: Thank you everyone for the replies! My breasts were really swollen right before my period (which I'm having right now) so I was really worried about what that local needle would feel like. The pain is much better than before so hopefully it won't be as bad. My BS wouldn't have been my biggest fan if the biopsy was done a few days ago. I'd squirm right off the table. I might do that anyway from nervousness, but at least it won't be from pain. I'm sure it will hurt a little since my lump does hurt but hopefully nothing major. Will I be laying facing up or down? I've heard different things but maybe it depends on what type of biopsy.
Posts.Title: Preparing for biopsy Lavender250 Gottobme

But benign probably means endless follow-ups and constant second guessing the next move. Obviously we want benign but still.  I hope you find out before the weekend too! It wouldn;t be right to make you wait much longer than the time they said. It's preetty standard to wait a week.... I think that's ridiculous. Thinking of you!

Posts.Title: Biopsy Today... chconnol momoftwo526

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2011 10:17AM Lavender250 wrote: I genuinely hope that these misdiagnosed cases are the exception. I would have been so angry to be your great aunt going through that. Did she end up being okay? Was she diagnosed within the last 15 years? The only reason for that kind of medical incompetence would be maybe during a time when screening wasn't so good. I get what you are saying. For me, I'd rather go from an ultrasound straight to a biopsy than  ultrasound, mammo and biopsy. Mammo seems unncessary as it only holds up the process more... but I guess they have to locate the lump to biopsy it. I don't know your age but I hear that mammos are better for women over 35. So maybe they can locate this thing and they will make better decisions from here on. My thoughts are with you and continue to hope for something harmless.
Posts.Title: Back again..... Biopsy Trabby Trabby

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2011 09:23AM Lavender250 wrote: I keep hearing about palpable breast lumps not showing up on scans. How can this be? So many women get diagnosed before a lump can even be felt. How can they not see something that is actually there? I understand not being able to tell what it is... but they should at least be able to locate it. This really makes it seem like mammos and ultrasounds aren't good diagnostic tools. Which stinks because biopsies really scare people and should only be used when necessary. It's starting to seem like every lump needs to go through the whole diagnostic process. Waiting through every imaginable test sucks the life out of many of us. I thought mammos and ultrasounds had a purpose and now I'm starting to wonder.....  As for your situation, I hope it all turns out well. Perhaps an enlarged node can also be benign. Wishing you the very best.
Posts.Title: Back again..... Biopsy Trabby Trabby

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2011 10:46AM - edited Aug 11, 2011 10:48AM by Lavender250 So glad you are doing better! I know with benign or cancerous lumps, it really changes people. It touches my heart to see people handling the diagnosis with such strength. I've always been envious of that attitude! My mother also had IBC (apparently). My sources are unreliable at this point about the specifics. I was shocked to learn about her having that kind because it's supposed to be very rare. I'm so glad you are fighting the good fight and helping others. You seem like a wonderful person!!! Thank you for the encouragement. I don't plan on giving up without a fight but I do fear that my time might have run out. My negligence is something I'm very ashamed about given my known medical history.
Posts.Title: Fibrocystic Breasts Lavender250 Springtime

Posts.Content: Lavender250 wrote: Ok ladies. I'm having a hard time with what this actually means and was hoping for some help. Most of the sites I read explain Fibrocystic Breasts as cysts or "fibrous tissue". What does that mean exactly? Some sites say rope-like or ridge-like tissue. What is that? Can a fibrocystic lump be irregular and complete unlike any other part of the breast? Is there such a thing as having a fibrocystic breast issue in only one breast? Can the pain be constant? One more question for my increasingly worried mind. Since normal tissue can have texture to it, is it possible for a cyst to grow underneath that texture? Making it seem irregular and rough because it's under the tissue? Or am I grasping at straws? My lump feels almost exactly like a breast cancer lump is described...only it's painful to touch and seems moveable. I don't know if it's fixed to anything but it moves between my fingers. On my other breast, there is a similar texture in the tissue but no lump. So I was wondering if it was possible for a cyst to grow under that lumpy tissue? I don't know. I'm desperate, especially at 27, to believe that this could be nothing but it sounds like cancer. I even saw a picture of a removed piece of cancer and it "looked" how my lump "felt". I'm being horribly pessimistic and I'm so sorry for that but I have nobody to talk to that understands. I'm drowning in my own fears. XOXO Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Fibrocystic Breasts Lavender250 Springtime

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2011 10:16AM Lavender250 wrote: I hope you are doing okay now, Holly! That is such a scary thing and I'm in a similar situation without insurance. I can't even accept the possibility of cancer so accepting the reality would be impossible. I'm not a very strong person and I'm not too young for cancer apparently but I'm too young to feel like my life is over. I know it's reasonable to keep a good attitude but I think most women experiencing a breast lump go into panic mode. Some more severe than others. I wonder how many people on this board with a worrisome lump (i.e., irregular or suspicious) were able to keep calm through the process. My family keeps telling me to calm down and that I can't do this to myself. I agree for the most part but I also know that it's always different when it's happening to you. For me, reacting to the possibility is as bad as the reality. Unfortunately, I do have a pretty nasty family history and a lump that makes my heart stop when I touch it. I still appreciate all you lovely women for trying to help me. I want to be brave so bad!
Posts.Title: Fibrocystic Breasts Lavender250 Springtime

Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2011 09:02AM - edited Aug 26, 2011 09:12AM by Lavender250 That's the next thing I was going to ask... if there were other specialists in your area.  Are there any general surgeons? Correct me if I'm wrong but don't all general surgeons deal with breast concerns? My sister sees a general surgeon for her breast care. I know you probably prefer a breast expert but I didn't know if there were any alternatives in your area. I know what you mean. I never went to the doctor before finding my lump and now I'm constantly pestering the nurses. I feel like I'm being annoying, espeically if I'm taking away time from actually diagnosed people, but lumps are scary to deal with. I love your attitude! 92 is a great, ripe age! I love it! Plus you promised your husband... you can't break a promise!! Best of luck to you! Keep us posted!  Marie: Let me rephrase. Ultrasound is the best "practical" screening test for dense breasts  My BS thought an MRI would raise more questions than answer them. And I thought I heard insurance didn't cover them but is that right? But you are definitely right that MRI would get the best images. Shiver. I hate MRI machines.
Posts.Title: more symptoms and 2 weeks to specialist 3beans Lavender250

Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2011 11:20AM Lavender250 wrote: Hahaha 3beans, I know right? I'm more open about my boobs than every before. I even let my sister touch my lump. That was a first. Thank you 3beans - I don;t have an appointment today but on friday @ 1:00 for my dreaded biopsy. I'm also intrigued by the idea that ultrasound didn't pick up my lump or yours. It angers me actually cause my radiologist made it sound like the best news in the world that they couldn't sonographically locate it. Once I spoke to my BS, she basically said, "yeah that happens." I thought ultrasounds were pretty good at finding something there even if they can't immediately identify it. My lump is not golf ball size or anything but it's not tiny either. In fact, my "cyst" showed up on US and it was deeper in the tissue than this current one. Kinda smaller, but definitely more solid. Still, can't get over how this new one never showed on imaging. I should have gone to the breast surgeon before doing the ultrasound. Might have saved me some time. I know what you are saying about aches and pains! I know it might be emotional despair causing it but you never know. I really do see now that my emotional response has been extreme. I think it's understandable, but I'm definitely in way too deep now so that could be causing pain. If you are anything like me, you could be having the same situation. I'm glad you are getting it checked out and I'm still praying that you not only get good news but SOOOOOOON! XOXO
Posts.Title: more symptoms and 2 weeks to specialist 3beans Lavender250

Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2011 10:34AM Lavender250 wrote: My husband is the polar opposite... which is both comforting and infuriating at the same time. He's Mr. Optimistic even though he has no real facts about my situation. It's nice to hear someone say "Everything will be okay" but then you don't want to have false hope. He's very naive and innocent. He's never had any tragic loss in his life and anxiety is not a part of his life at all. So it's really difficult confiding in him sometimes because he just wants to hope for the best. I love that about him and hate it. If this is bad news, I don't want to know that I had him whispering in my ear that it would be okay. Some kind of balance in between would be nice. This is the place to be for empathy and support! No doubt about that! I really hope we both get some good news so we can breathe.
Posts.Title: more symptoms and 2 weeks to specialist 3beans Lavender250

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2011 09:24AM - edited Aug 27, 2011 09:29AM by Lavender250 I agree 3beans.... while I worry about taking time away from seriously ill patients, I don't want to feel discouraged by the clinical staff from asking questions as they come up. Everyone with a lump has to consider the possibility of something being wrong. I had a very abbreviated first visit with my surgeon and was overwhelmed with questions after. I have no insurance so making another appointment seems risky. I have no choice but to bother the nurse... which I've only done 3 times so far since the 15th.. but might have to bother at least one more time before my biopsy.  She told me to call anytime with questions but I'm sure I have a reputation by now of being an overly worried patient. I would hope that they understand that and have compassion for women in that circumstance. I have major trust issues with doctors and I'm sure the breast center staff has picked up on that by now. Only because I'm absolutely frazzled by how long it's taking to diagnosed this lump. I was floored that an ultrasound wouldn;t pick something up of this size. It's just been frustrating and it was all compounded by some of the worrying things that my surgeon said. I respect my surgeon but I'm very young... not too young for cancer... but young enough even with my personal experiences to be scared completely out of my wits. I hope the medical staff understands that.  I also agree that waiting is a living nightmare. I've been waiting 2 months now and my summer has been destroyed. My future plans are all on hold. My doctor has given me no reason to assume it will be okay so I'm stuck in this limbo phase. It's horrible. I also agree that no medical professional should treat a patient, especially a potential cancer patient, any differently because they are more anxious or difficult than others.
Posts.Title: more symptoms and 2 weeks to specialist 3beans Lavender250

Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2011 08:30AM Lavender250 wrote: When did you make your breast specialist appointment? That's a long wait but you might be from a busier area than me. Maybe keep calling to see if there has been a cancellation. I know all about the waiting game. I've been waiting two months to solve my breast problem. I'm also kept awake at night by odd aches and pains. I keep wondering why all of these symptoms cropped up only once I found the lump. Makes me wonder if I'm either going crazy or just REALLY unlucky. My lump also didn't show up on ultrasound. Since ultrasounds are allegedly the best tool for dense breasts, I didn't expect them to not find it. Mine is pretty obvious too.  I also didn't expect them to tell me that it was good news only to have my breast surgeon recommend a biopsy. It's difficult and you are absolutely not alone. You can always keep calling your doctor if you want the appointment moved up. Right now, your situation sounds similar to mine. Urgent to you but not necessarily to the docs. I wish I had more advice for you about your situation. Best thing I can offer to you is the reassurance that you aren't alone. I hope you will get benign results!!!!
Posts.Title: more symptoms and 2 weeks to specialist 3beans Lavender250

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2011 09:56AM Lavender250 wrote: My first experience with my breast surgeon was very awkward. Partly my fault, partly hers. I came with a list of questions and none of them mattered once she suggested a biopsy. Then she started worrying me by telling me that it could be cancer, that biopsies could produce errors, etc. All bets were off and I was stunned into silence. It was weird. I hope she is more personable during the biopsy and I hope to build a better relationship with her. I was just so messed up with fear the first time around! I don't want to be a pest... but not sure I can help it.

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2011 01:03AM Lavender250 wrote: I'm going through something similar. I'm 27 and am constantly looking for lumps now. I hadn't been for many years and now it's all I think about. Once you find a growth, it really changes how you handle future ones - benign or not. It's seriously impossible to cope with so I completely understand how you feel. I'll be thinking of you and hoping for a benign result like the other one. People keep telling me that a pretty good percentage of lumps are harmless. That's definitely something to remember. However, I'd be a hypocrite to tell you to calm down when I can't do that myself! I'll keep you in my thoughts. You are are not alone in how you feel!
Posts.Title: Just when I thought it was safe... what_ifs stjude10

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2011 11:55AM Lavender250 wrote: I appreciate all the warm thoughts. Sincerely.  I think my worry is exacerbated by my inability to pay and not knowing how bad my condition might be. I don't qualify for assistance because I earn just above the limit. Will they even treat you if you don't have insurance? I know you are right about saving my anxiety for the real issue (whatever it may be) but I guess my concern is how long I've neglected the problem. I was not doing self exams and did not see a doctor for several years prior to this recent appointment. I feel like my chances are slimmer than other women my age. Still, thank you. I'm at work and my anxiety has been out of control and having you guys here for me is so meaningful. Working has been my #1 tension because I feel trapped when I start having anxiety. I'm trying so hard to avoid skipping work but I've been skipping more than I wanted to.
Posts.Title: New lump, here we go again Lavender250 Linda-n3

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2011 11:29AM - edited Aug 14, 2011 11:32AM by Lavender250 What I'm starting to find particularly alarming about my "lumps" is that the pain hasn't been subsiding. I've always had general pain in the areas where my lumps are. Since I considered it a bilateral occurence, I assumed it was cyclical and never checked for lumps until last month. I'm not one to touch my boobs often or even do breast exams but my breasts NEVER hurt like this all the time. Could this soreness really be caused by my constant touching?? If so, how does it go from not really hurting to being excruciaitng? It REALLY hurts to touch but it kinda hurts on its own too. Even my lump in my other breast, the "so-called cyst" is still causing me a great deal of pain and I rarely touch that one now. In an effort to compare the upper part of my left breast to my right, I am now feeling pain in the top part of my left breast, where there is no lump that I can feel. What is with all this pain? I've been touching my right breast constantly but not my left. There's pain everywhere. I'm getting so frustrated from all these issues happening at one time.

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2011 11:41AM Lavender250 wrote:
Posts.Title: New lump, here we go again Lavender250 Linda-n3

Posts.Content: Lavender250 wrote: Hi guys, Was not expecting to be back so soon. After getting cleared for the lump in my left  breast, I'm going in for the right now. I had been noticing pain in my right breast and found a mass. It's more long than wide. The doctor described it as "oblong". It's moveable but hard. It's irregular to me because of its oblong shape. Most of it feels smooth but there's a part on the end that feels textured. It's more square  shaped than round although it does move easily. It hurts so much to touch. My appointment was a bummer as the doctor didn't really examine me as much as I would have wanted. I'm not insured so all of this is costing a fortune. $115 to have her briefly examine the lump. It was not a complete exam by any means. It was all very disappointing. She then told me I  could either go to a breast specialist or get another ultrasound. The last ultrasound cost me almost $200 and it wasn't even a full breast ultrasound. This is all so overwhelming to me. The doctor seems to think this is benign but I don't know where she's getting that from. She really didn't inspect it very much. Also, since it doesn't really feel like a cyst, what's the point of the ultrasound? Here's the kicker... my ultrasound is two weeks away!!! Is that a normal waiting time for a palpable, painful mass? I can't see myself waiting that long after what I went through before. At least my other lump was round and smooth. This new lump is pretty irregular which means that a cyst is not likely. I could potentially spend all month investigating this horrible lump. I'm hoping someone has some insight. I appreciate your input so much! Thanks! Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: New lump, here we go again Lavender250 Linda-n3

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2011 03:31PM - edited Aug 18, 2011 03:32PM by Lavender250
Posts.Title: cysts pastalover pastalover

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2011 05:00AM Lavender250 wrote: I understand exactly what you mean. Even the Radiology scheduler seemed surprised that I'm going in for another ultrasound after I just had one on the other breast. There's something unsettling about an ultrasound tech telling you there's nothing to worry about when everyone else says that biopsy is the only true diagnostic tool. I want to obey the doctors but I don't want to be brushed off either. I have a crippling anxiety about doctors to begin with so I'm always tempted to take the easier way out of medical things. If I live to tell the tale of this experience, it will change my whole outlook on healthcare. I'll be constantly looking over my shoulder and worried about what the doctor might have missed. Or wondering if the "benign" thing turns malignant over time. It's definitely good that your doctor seems to really care about you AND you are not alone in your feelings. I think this type of "scare" really wakes people up to the potential dangers out there. I wish it didn't have to be that way though.  There's a certain charm to blissful ignorance and I miss it terribly! XOXO and best of luck.

Posts.Title: Scared CindyT Kimmer1975

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2011 05:46PM - edited Aug 10, 2011 05:47PM by Lavender250 Are there any benign growths that could be rough in texture? I'm getting increasingly unsettled by my lack of findings on this. There's nothing I can find. My lump is squarish with sorta sharp edges and feels textured on the surface. It's moveable between my fingers and hurts. I can't find anything that this could be besides cancer. I'm 27 so this would be such a horrible turn of events for me. It actually doesn't appear to be that rare to have get BC in this age group. I'm just surprised I would get such a big lump. My mom had IBC @ 44 and died @ 46. That's young by most standards but probably increases my chances of getting it even younger. I'm a mess and I'm sorry for being such a downer all the time. But I'm scared to go to an ultrasound with no real reason to expect good news. At least my other lump had features that could be benign. Yikes ... thanks for whatever info you guys have!
Posts.Title: Walnut size? Rough cyst? Lavender250 marie5890

Posts.Content: Lavender250 wrote: I'm sorry if this is off topic... but as I've said before, I'm uninsured and am planning to get married very soon. My fiancee works at a hospital that "claims" they don't have a pre-existing  clause. Does that mean that I would be covered if I do end up having cancer? No strings attached. He keeps trying to phrase it in different ways to them to make sure. I get worried because his HR lady keeps saying that I will be covered even with a pre-existing  condition whther I had previous insurance or not. She sounds so certain but I worry about this because breast cancer is a major disease. It's an expensive disease. If I'm diagnosed right around the time my coverage starts, I can't help but worry that there will be some denial of coverage. Can anyone help me? I'm already stressed enough about having such serious lumps at my age but worrying about not being able to treat it only adds more pressure and despair. Thanks! I kinda fall through the cracks with most other plans so I'm feeling desperate and scared. Side note: My fiancee is not mentioning to HR that I have or might have cancer. He was just asking about their pre-existing condition rule in general. I'd still like to think that the HR lady would have mentioned exceptions if there were any. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: It never really ends Lavender250 zouping

Posts.Content: Aug 5, 2011 01:29AM - edited Aug 5, 2011 01:37AM by Lavender250 I'm right there with you. My ultrasound is on the 12th for lump numero dos. Finding my first lump at 27 has been surreal but much more so to find another in the same month. It's just pure terror. This web site is helpful to me because we are a community of like-minded people. Many women here have gone through the actual diagnosis and treatment. They are amazing! Everyone is telling me to calm down but I'd rather be told to calm down by people on this board :-) There are so many great women here! and maybe a few men too!  St. Jude - I'm sorry to hear about what you are going through but am glad you were persistent. I hope your treatment goes well! This is precisely what terrifies me most about breast cancer. How could your lump not show up on mammo OR ultrasound? That's so scary. It makes me feel like a biopsy is required for every lump. I was told my lump in my left breast was a cluster of cysts. Can I really trust that? I'm really afraid that this new lump will either be dismissed or not properly examined. Do you mind my asking --- how big is your lump? I'm so sorry to hear your news. I'm so disappointed that your doctors missed it! I admire your determination so much.
Posts.Title: Just when I thought it was safe... what_ifs stjude10

Posts.Content: Lavender250 wrote: When someone says "walnut sized" - do they mean the shell or the actual nut ? My mind is running wild today and was just curious.  Also - is there such a thing as a "rough textured" cyst? Or are they always smooth? Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Walnut size? Rough cyst? Lavender250 marie5890

Posts.Content: Lavender250 wrote: Hi everyone. First off let me say that I admire the fact that so many cancer sufferers and survivors are willing to join this board and help people. It's just amazing to see. Courage to you all!  I'm 27 years old. My mother had breast cancer in her early 40's and my grandmother had ovarian in her 50's. I haven't been to the doctor in several years and found a lump last week in my breast. It's roughly the size of a skitte, perhaps bigger. It moves but does feel attached to something. I would say it's quite hard and can be quite painful... especially when I'm touching it.  I made an appointment to see a doctor last week and she 'believes' it to be a cyst. She also said that cancer would be unlikely even with my family history. I also mentioned that there was a blue vein very close to the lump and she didn't seem concerned. I left  feeling pretty good but then started to realize that my history is so strong and my lump characteristics are still suspicious to me. I have an ultrasound scheduled for next wednesday but I'm so scared that this is cancer. My quality of life since finding the lump has beem abismal. I can't function and I'm crying all the time. Mostly because I have no insurance. I'm so young but I know my risk is very high. I just don't know what to think or do. I feel pretty hopeless.  In summary,  the lump is skittle-sized, hard, moveable but feels anchored to something. It's painful.... was more painful during and before my period. I have blue veins in both my breasts but there's a specific blue vein over my lump. Could this still be a cyst? I know my doctor saying that should have given me some hope but it didn't. Thank you so much to anyone who can guide me!!!!! Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Breast lump @ 27, strong family history Lavender250 del4

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2011 12:21PM - edited Jul 15, 2011 12:24PM by Lavender250 Thanks guys! You are helping me more than anyone has so far. It's hard because my boyfriend is trying to keep me positive and my sister is hysterical like me. It's nice to talk to people who have been through something and I'm so thankful to you. I'm also glad that many of you are healthy evcen after dealing with this illness.  Cycle-path: I'm sorry, I should clarify. My doctor didn't say that I would never ever get cancer. She suggested genetic counseling and dicussed with me that screening should start earlier than 40 for me.  I think she meant that *THIS* particular lump is unlikely to be cancer given my age... despite the family history. I want to believe her so badly but I don't. I will try to keep myself calm but this is a horrible feeling. My mother died from her cancer and it really took her down. She was depressed for the entirety of her treatment.... so much so that it delayed her treatment. I don't want to go through that at my age. It's so difficult to think about but your support has been helpful!  Hugs right back to you all
Posts.Title: Breast lump @ 27, strong family history Lavender250 del4

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2011 06:28PM Lavender250 wrote: I'll definitely stay and be a supportive member of this board. Y'all are angels! You really are! My mom had a horrible time when she had cancer and I know this type of community would have helped her! I'll keep you all in my thoughts and prayers. I'm still hoping that I can trust the radiology team and try to have a life again!
Posts.Title: Breast lump @ 27, strong family history Lavender250 del4

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2011 07:35AM - edited Jul 21, 2011 07:37AM by Lavender250 Not that I'm trying to be paranoid or anything.... but is it normal for there to be no follow-up with a palpable, painful cyst? Or "cluster of cysts"? I'm trying to rejoice in this news but it's hard. Also, does anyone know if it's possible that she picked up the wrong cyst by accident? I just worry because she seemed a little eager to tell me it was nothing... even though it's obviously something. Cysts don't usually hurt this much. It's hard and can be felt very easily. I also keep hearing that people under 30 don't normally get cysts and that palpable cysts are uncommon. I hate to say it but I might have to get a second opinion. I'm not able to completely relax because I'm paranoid that she didn't examine the right cyst. I'm sorry to bother you all with these questions but my boyfriend just wants me to be happy about the news.... and I don't want to jump the gun on celebrating.
Posts.Title: Breast lump @ 27, strong family history Lavender250 del4

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2011 09:13PM Lavender250 wrote: This has certainly been an eye opening experience for me. I knew that diagnosing by breast exam alone could be a risky situation but I always thought mammograms and ultrasounds were reliable tools to get someone to their next phase. I'm seeing more and more people say that their cancer or lump was not found by these diagnostic tests. Seems like something is very wrong there. I can only imagine that being the reason why 85% of  biopsied lumps are benign. 85% are not detected on imaging, so 85% are benign. Give or take. I hate to hear about women going through biopsies when it could have been avoided.

People who look like their mother or father might have all or most of their genes. But obviously there's no scientific link and it's not even a consideration in a risk assessment. I just didn't know what you all thought. Thanks! Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Genetic link and physical appearance? Lavender250 slousha

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2011 06:10AM - edited Aug 11, 2011 06:11AM by Lavender250 Thanks Meme...  Unfortunately, it could be state 4 for all I know. I haven't been to the doctor in years before now and never did breast exams. I think that's where all the overwhelming anxiety is coming from. This lump is already very very big so I could be in advanced stages. I'm so scared. I should hear back about the anxiety meds today but I'm still pretty sure I can't handle anything that is happening right now. I feel bad because I know I don't have any real answers yet.... just a strong hunch based on how it feels. I can't get comfortable and never can go back to sleep once the butterflies start. xo
Posts.Title: Walnut size? Rough cyst? Lavender250 marie5890

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2011 10:17AM Lavender250 wrote: Thank you Marie. I'm so concerned by the texture and size of my lump. Even though pain isn't a typical sign of cancer, it definitely  can be and certainly if a lump is large. I'm worried about when this thing started growing for it to become this size already. It's not fast growing as far as I can tell. It's been stable for the last month (I think) so it's not some overly rapid growth. I know women can get this at any age but it seems particularly rare in the 20-25 age range. It scares me that this thing could have been growing since those young ages. I've glanced at the threat with those brave young cancer sufferers and most of them discovered their lumps when they were small. Not everyone, but most of them. I'm so concerned but I hope you are right. I can't stand the idea of going for an ultrasound with absolutely no hope for a benign outcome. I appreciate all of you and can't stand not being able to calm down.
Posts.Title: Walnut size? Rough cyst? Lavender250 marie5890

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2011 11:19AM - edited Jul 15, 2011 11:21AM by Lavender250 Thank you for your thoughts so far.  I guess the other part that is worrying me is the fact that the lump feels stuck to something. It's round/oval in shape and smooth. However, I  can't get behind the lump with my finger because it seems stuck to something. It moves between my fingers and the doctor said it was 'moveable' but I don't understand why it feels stuck to something. Can a cyst be that way or are they supposed to move freely? I've had a cysts on my eye and behind my ear drained. You;d think that a cyst could be stuck to your breast.... so is it possible that a benign breast cyst could move on the top but still feel anchored to my breast? My lump is also pretty hard. Does this still seem like it could be a cyst? Thanks again!
Posts.Title: Breast lump @ 27, strong family history Lavender250 del4

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2011 02:10PM Lavender250 wrote: I'm back from my appointment.  According to the tech, she is close to 100% sure that the lump is a benign cluster of cysts! I was so relieved.... yet I'm still very cautious now. What are my best followup options as she didn't offer me any? She said this was good news and sent me on my way. I'm so happy but value all your opinions -- what should be my next course of action? Should I be suspicious of these findings? I've heard stories about cancer hiding under cysts. Also, can I be fairly confident that she would have found this lump on her own? I tried pointing it out but was not totally sure that she spotted it. Thank you for your prayers and/or thoughts! I love this board and appreciate you all so much.
Posts.Title: Breast lump @ 27, strong family history Lavender250 del4

Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2011 03:02PM Lavender250 wrote: Thanks for your reply. Are you for real? Could they really delay my ultrasound because of insurance ?? That seems so unethical to me. I'm living in Maine, albeit the most populated area of Maine, but two weeks does seem ridiculous. My doctor kept calling me "low risk" even though my mother died of BC at age 46. She felt that my lump was benign. I plan on calling tomorrow to see if I can change this but I probably won't be successful. I'm worried about my physical and mental state between now and then. Anybody know what I should do? I never realized that my insurance status could put my at the bottom of the list. I'm 27... could age be a factor? Obviously my doctor doesn't think this is urgent.. but anyone at any age wants an answer ASAP. Especially since the ultrasound is not necessarily going to answer anything. There could be an even longer wait to investigate this further. I'm feeeling so beaten down right now. Thank you kindly for your input.... and I hope you are now doing well!
Posts.Title: New lump, here we go again Lavender250 Linda-n3

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2011 07:33AM Lavender250 wrote: Thanks HappyTrisha for your kind words. Can a fibroadenoma be irregular shaped and painful? Is there anything benign that can be long rather than round? It moves around quite easily but it hurts and feels more oblong. It also has a spot on it that has some texture to it. I'm just worried to wait that long for an u/s when it's already showing signs of not being a cyst. Can cysts be irregular shaped? My other lump was a "cluster" of cysts but it was at least round. Not having a round lump makes me more worried.
Posts.Title: New lump, here we go again Lavender250 Linda-n3

Posts.Content: Lavender250 wrote: Hi guys, Was not expecting to be back so soon. After getting cleared for the lump in my left  breast, I'm going in for the right now. I had been noticing pain in my right breast and found a mass. It's more long than wide. The doctor described it as "oblong". It's moveable but hard. It's irregular to me because of its oblong shape. Most of it feels smooth but there's a part on the end that feels textured. It's more square  shaped than round although it does move easily. It hurts so much to touch. My appointment was a bummer as the doctor didn't really examine me as much as I would have wanted. I'm not insured so all of this is costing a fortune. $115 to have her briefly examine the lump. It was not a complete exam by any means. It was all very disappointing. She then told me I  could either go to a breast specialist or get another ultrasound. The last ultrasound cost me almost $200 and it wasn't even a full breast ultrasound. This is all so overwhelming to me. The doctor seems to think this is benign but I don't know where she's getting that from. She really didn't inspect it very much. Also, since it doesn't really feel like a cyst, what's the point of the ultrasound? Here's the kicker... my ultrasound is two weeks away!!! Is that a normal waiting time for a palpable, painful mass? I can't see myself waiting that long after what I went through before. At least my other lump was round and smooth. This new lump is pretty irregular which means that a cyst is not likely. I could potentially spend all month investigating this horrible lump. I'm hoping someone has some insight. I appreciate your input so much! Thanks! Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: New lump, here we go again Lavender250 Linda-n3

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2011 06:13PM Lavender250 wrote: I'm devastated.... apparently I need a biopsy but my surgeon didn't really care when. I was hoping for some medical guidance and all I got were decisions thrown at me. I don't currently have insurance but I'd happily pay for a biopsy out of pocket for piece of mind. My surgeon wanted me to wait until my newlywed coverage starts in September. At least 2.5 weeks away. She told me she thought it was benign but didn't explain why even when I asked. She didn't seem to care at all if I did a biopsy. I don't get it. Can someone explain this to me? Nothing shows up on ultrasound, she feels the lump, and why is it not urgent to biopsy it?? I don't understand and I was too emotional to ask all my questions. She was not a good surgeon and I felt very empty inside when I left. Like I had all the time in the world to figure this out. I explained to her that I never did breast exams and never saw the doctor. Nothing. She didn't seem to care. She was really bad, worse than I was expecting by far. Now I'm just really really sad and need you guys more than ever! :(
Posts.Title: New lump, here we go again Lavender250 Linda-n3

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2011 03:06PM Lavender250 wrote: It keeps inching closer and closer.... My lump definitely feels cancerous.  It's irregular and has ridges all over it. I don't know what a ridge is but that's the best word I can find. It's a lump with what feels like little bumps and all over it. I haven't seen any information about any benign conditions that feel like that. There's pain and it's mobile but that's about it. Everything else leans to cancer. How am I supposed to deal with this? I know many of you women are so strong but I'm just not able to deal with this. I did call my doctor though and they will be getting me some meds. Other than that, I'm feeling really hopeless. At least my other lump had clear features. This new lump feels worse every day. It's already really big and the little notches all over the lump have me VERY concerned.
Posts.Title: New lump, here we go again Lavender250 Linda-n3

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2011 11:52PM Lavender250 wrote: I understand your concern, coolbreeze, and your post actually was empowering in some way. But I'm thinking more about the countless posts on this very board that claim their palpable lump/cancer was not found on imaging scans. That really stayed with me and has been playing with my brain. It's hard to believe that mammos and u/s scans wouldn't at least locate a mass whether they can completely identify it or not. It's gonna be a source of confusion for me. I do have an appointment with a breast surgeon and I will definitely ask many questions. I'm also taking anxiety meds which, as you can see, are not working but I'm really seeking some input about what we do as patients in these situations. Would the average person on this board believe a radiologist that says a palpable lump is not showing on a scan? I have nothing against seeing a breast surgeon but I waited two painfully long weeks for this ultrasound that found nothing. One plus about this breast surgeon is that she is seeing me immediately. I should have gone straight to her in the first place, As a selfpay patient, I don't think there would have been any hoops to jump through. Thank you all for your tough love and constant support. I completely understand what a basketcase I have been. I do think this is an appropriate place for questions, concerns, grief, and anxiety. Unfortunately for you guys, anxiety is up at bat right now :-)
Posts.Title: New lump, here we go again Lavender250 Linda-n3

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2011 11:09AM Lavender250 wrote: Thanks meme. I know some people would take that ultrasound as good news but not me. I know my body. I know this lump is not right and I'm expecting a really bad outcome even though you lovely ladies don't want me thinking like that. It's just a feeling I get whenever I touch it and whenever someone elbows me in the area and it hurts like crazy. I can't believe the ultrasound didn't detect even one small aspect of this thing and I'm truly afraid of what the breast surgeon will say. All I want to do is hide from this now. I was doing okay yesterday because my family wants me to think that the ultrasound meant I was okay. I'm too informed to believe that. Not only does my lump feel horrible but so many women on this board have been led astray with their breast problems. Like you, I'm not normally this anxious. I did have mild anxiety disorder or at least anxiety I could function with. This is severe anxiety like I've never experienced in my whole life. With some depression and weepiness thrown in.  I just want to be around long enough to have a family and marry my boyfriend. If I could get the all clear about this, I'd live my life so differently. I wouldn't ask God to spare me cancer... rather I would just take better care of myself so I'd have a fighting chance if I did get the disease. I pray everyday and I can't thank you enough for your prayers.

I don't have insurance but will within a month or so. IF I'm lucky enough to make it another month then I will be getting followups for sure. I can't live with the unknowns. Posts.Title: New lump, here we go again Lavender250 Linda-n3

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2011 10:58AM - edited Aug 3, 2011 10:58AM by Lavender250 All of my stress is compounded by the fact that I haven't seen a doctor in several years prior to this and never did breast exams. IF this is cancer then I probably don't stand a chance as it's gotten to be so big and painful. These lumps could have been here for years without my knowing. I almost wish I never found the lump so my quality of life could return. I know I'm being annoyingly pessimistic but I have really bad circumstances. No insurance and haven't been checked in years. All I do is cry and beg God to spare me until I at least am insured. Getting through the work week is horrible. I want a clean slate so badly. Thank you all for your kindness. I honestly don't know what I'd do without you!!! There's nobody in my regular life that "gets it"! xo
Posts.Title: New lump, here we go again Lavender250 Linda-n3

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2011 10:52AM Lavender250 wrote: My ultrasound is friday and this has been TORTURE. It was going okay at first but the past few days have been horrible. I wanted to take the advice of getting some Ativan but chickened out. I was sleeping/eating okay and now not so much. I've had this phlegm build up/tickle in my throat for a couple years and now I'm starting to worry that the cancer has spread to my lungs. I'm fearing that the cancer has been inside me for a long time and is spreading around. I'm the worst when it comes to worrying and I'm almost maxed out. I had plans to marry my boyfriend and now I don't think I'll be around to do that. I keep blaming myself for not seeing a doctor sooner and maybe having a chance to treat this... but I have no insurance anyway. I've been so depressed. Mostly because this ultrasound could easily be inconclusive and the worrying will continue. My lump moves but is "irregular" in shape and rough to the touch. It's an inch long and maybe a centimeter wide or so. I haven't read about anything benign that has those features. It's painful but that might be because it's been growing inside me for years. There's nothing "cyst-like" about it yet my only diagnostic path is ultrasound. This agony is nowhere near over and I'm so afraid of dying before I've had a chance to live. I also just found out that my mother had inflammatory breast cancer. I knew she had breast cancer but never knew what kind. IBC is the deadliest and most aggressive type. I'm sure that only increases my chances of getting the same disease or something similar. People say it's "rare" to get cancer before 35 but it doesn't seem that rare. Plus "rare" has a different meaning to people with a family history. IBC is very rare yet my mom still got it. I've completely lost hope and getting through the day is impossible. I just needed to vent. Is there really any hope with a lump like mine? It seems destined to be bad just by how it feels.
Posts.Title: New lump, here we go again Lavender250 Linda-n3

Posts.Title: New lump, here we go again Lavender250 Linda-n3

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2011 06:21AM Lavender250 wrote: Hi everyone, What can I expect from my breast surgeon? I have an appointment this afternoon and am very nervous. I was wondering what the typical first visit is like. I'm getting married this weekend so I'm a little afraid of her scaring me with grim findings or making me do procedures before my wedding. I wanted to touch base with her but now I'm afraid of what I'll find out. Will she flat out tell me it's cancer just by touching it? I'm always very nervous about the kinds of doctors that blurt out their best guess about this stuff. I have a wedding to plan and I don't want it be totally ruined by this assessment. I'm just asking those with experience what I should expect. I'm just going crazy even after taking a Lorazepam.
Posts.Title: New lump, here we go again Lavender250 Linda-n3

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2011 06:34AM - edited Aug 16, 2011 06:35AM by Lavender250 Thanks everyone. I know that an urgent biopsy would have scared me more but I can't help feeling like her assessment was money driven. I didn;t get the sense that she really knew what was going on with me. I tried explaining to her that I hadn't been doing monthly exams and never saw the doctor. She didn't seem to get it. Yes it's true that some cancers are slow growing and can wait a week to a couple months for evaluation. But what if I've had my lump since age 23? 24? 25? There's no way of knowing because I didn't see a doctor then. Also, I forgot to have her check my lump with my arm down (it's way more noticeable with my arm down) and now I'm reeling about that. I pictured something so different in my head. I pictured a calming room with a patient doctor that would sweetly answer my questions. I got a lady who was generally dismissing me for my age (even though there were two women under 35 in the waiting room, one clearly had cancer). I don't want to be brushed off for my age. I'd rather be brushed off because her "expert hands" didn't think it seemed cancerous. I want a better attitude and I want to calm down but it's not happening. The waiting has beeen the worst and I worry that my lack of insurance is going to get me subpar care everywhere I go. I have this strange feeling that even if this was a highly suspicious lump (which it still could be), that I still wouldn't have gotten an urgent biopsy. Peace with you all and I'm going to TRY to enjoy my wedding but I'm in such a sad place. I didn't get enough reassurance from my doctor to justify such a long wait for a biopsy.
Posts.Title: New lump, here we go again Lavender250 Linda-n3

Posts.Content: Lavender250 wrote: Hi everyone. First off let me say that I admire the fact that so many cancer sufferers and survivors are willing to join this board and help people. It's just amazing to see. Courage to you all!  I'm 27 years old. My mother had breast cancer in her early 40's and my grandmother had ovarian in her 50's. I haven't been to the doctor in several years and found a lump last week in my breast. It's roughly the size of a skitte, perhaps bigger. It moves but does feel attached to something. I would say it's quite hard and can be quite painful... especially when I'm touching it.  I made an appointment to see a doctor last week and she 'believes' it to be a cyst. She also said that cancer would be unlikely even with my family history. I also mentioned that there was a blue vein very close to the lump and she didn't seem concerned. I left  feeling pretty good but then started to realize that my history is so strong and my lump characteristics are still suspicious to me. I have an ultrasound scheduled for next wednesday but I'm so scared that this is cancer. My quality of life since finding the lump has beem abismal. I can't function and I'm crying all the time. Mostly because I have no insurance. I'm so young but I know my risk is very high. I just don't know what to think or do. I feel pretty hopeless.  In summary,  the lump is skittle-sized, hard, moveable but feels anchored to something. It's painful.... was more painful during and before my period. I have blue veins in both my breasts but there's a specific blue vein over my lump. Could this still be a cyst? I know my doctor saying that should have given me some hope but it didn't. Thank you so much to anyone who can guide me!!!!! Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2011 02:25PM Lavender250 wrote: Well that was a bust.... can't believe what a waste of time this was. Two weeks of crippling anxiety to get to this diagnosis... "we don't see anything there". I guess you can add me to the club of disillusioned patients. The exam itself was agony.  While the tech seemed more thorough than the other one, she asked me many questions about my genetic family history. This made me automatically think something was wrong. Like she was correlating my young age at diagnosis with my history. Then she leaves for what feels like forever and brings the radiologist with her. I almost had a heart attack right there. He proceeded to tell me that nothing was found on the ultrasound. He said for peace of mind I could go to a breast surgeon. Not sure how long that will take and I'm pretty sure if not more sure than ever that I have cancer. Apparently just not the kind that radiologist can detect. He kept telling me it was good news and I was just depressed. I tried asking him how they couldn';t find a lump that is large. What does an ultrasound do again? I think I have ILC or IBC. That explains what feels like a thick, painful, flat, bumpy chunk mass in my breast that an ultrasound can't find. I'm so distraught because I was secretly hoping for answers. Now the biopsy is not even scheduled to happen unless I refer myself to a breast surgeon. Only then will I get the diagnosis I've been waiting for for almost two months. Glad I have the ativan now... I'm going to need it.
Posts.Title: New lump, here we go again Lavender250 Linda-n3

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2011 07:41AM Lavender250 wrote: I agree about waiting until the final results are in to tell your children. I know cancer seems very likely to you right now but you never know. That's why they don't usually diagnose based on imaging alone. There's no way to know for sure without that biopsy. Other than that, I would tell only adults that you want support from. If there's someone in your life that needs a bit of protection (i.e.,mother, sister) then I think you could wait to tell them if it would be too hard to tell them. It's a difficult situation when you don't actually know what's happening but most close relatives will benefit from knowing so they can pray for you or think positive thoughts for you. I really really really hope you get good news!
Posts.Title: Who to tell and when? AmyR AmyR

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2011 01:37PM Lavender250 wrote: It's the same thing with "mobility". People describe that in such different ways. Some say the lump moves all around the breast. Some say you can actually grab onto it. My doc said my lump was "mobile" but it only moves from the very top. It feels attached to "something" but moves a lot on the surface. Nobody really knows. My breast surgeon just told me that she thought mine was benign because of the length of it.... but I've seen a few people say they had a long lump. It's just maddening. I wish cancer had more noticeable characteristics. Biopsies are painful and stressful. It would be nice to have a few other ways to detect cancer.  As far as pain... I haven't been diagnosed yet.... but my pain is pretty bad on both lumps. My right side being the worst although I don't yet know if it's from touching it so much. I'm trying to stop touching so I can tell for sure. The pain is VERY sore when touched and mildly sore when not touched. It doesn't generally hurt on it's own and I'm more comfortable when I'm not touching it. I'm able to sleep on my stomach with no problems but it might be because my lump is closer to my armpit.
Posts.Title: Question about breast pain.......What's yours feel like? Rushell jessjoy

Posts.Content: Lavender250 wrote: Hi guys, Was not expecting to be back so soon. After getting cleared for the lump in my left  breast, I'm going in for the right now. I had been noticing pain in my right breast and found a mass. It's more long than wide. The doctor described it as "oblong". It's moveable but hard. It's irregular to me because of its oblong shape. Most of it feels smooth but there's a part on the end that feels textured. It's more square  shaped than round although it does move easily. It hurts so much to touch. My appointment was a bummer as the doctor didn't really examine me as much as I would have wanted. I'm not insured so all of this is costing a fortune. $115 to have her briefly examine the lump. It was not a complete exam by any means. It was all very disappointing. She then told me I  could either go to a breast specialist or get another ultrasound. The last ultrasound cost me almost $200 and it wasn't even a full breast ultrasound. This is all so overwhelming to me. The doctor seems to think this is benign but I don't know where she's getting that from. She really didn't inspect it very much. Also, since it doesn't really feel like a cyst, what's the point of the ultrasound? Here's the kicker... my ultrasound is two weeks away!!! Is that a normal waiting time for a palpable, painful mass? I can't see myself waiting that long after what I went through before. At least my other lump was round and smooth. This new lump is pretty irregular which means that a cyst is not likely. I could potentially spend all month investigating this horrible lump. I'm hoping someone has some insight. I appreciate your input so much! Thanks! Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: New lump, here we go again Lavender250 Linda-n3

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2011 06:05PM Lavender250 wrote: I'm so scared guys. Please keep me in your prayers and thoughts. I'm not going to do well tonight!
Posts.Title: New lump, here we go again Lavender250 Linda-n3

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2011 12:51PM - edited Aug 13, 2011 12:52PM by Lavender250 As always, you ladies are great. there are so many people saying their cancer wasn't found on u/s. I hope that's not the norm but I don't know. My lump I guess is more like hard, thick tissue that moves and hurts. Yet it felt palpable enough for it to show up on u/s. It makes me worry about IBC (my mom had) or ILC. I have an appointment with a breast surgeon on monday and will go from there. I.m terrified of needing BX. I just want someone to say I'm okay witbout the agonizing procedures. Theres so much pressure on how advanced this would be if it were cancer.I'm trying, I am.
Posts.Title: New lump, here we go again Lavender250 Linda-n3

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2011 12:50PM Lavender250 wrote: I just wouldn't want to deal with biopsy results and an invasive procedure during the week of my wedding. That's just not cool with me. I'm now very afraid that the doctor will tell me I have or might have cancer today. I wasn't expecting that. I thought this was a consultation. My fiancee works with a hospital and apparently has good coverage. His HR says they have no pre-existing clause. I know you didn't intend to but you really scared me with your post Amy! I'm tweaking.
Posts.Title: New lump, here we go again Lavender250 Linda-n3

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2011 01:22PM Lavender250 wrote: Hahaha, tweaking means freaking out. It's okay Amy. I know you are just trying to share your experience. We do all have different ones but I'm just really bad at taking horrible news. I've always been that way and always will. That's why I was kinda hoping for an easy-going first visit, not a full  blown cancer diagnosis. Anyway, yes I'm going with my fiancee. He's been my rock through everything and I'd love to be his wife for the longterm not just short term. Please God have mercy on me!!! Kisses to all you girls! Wish me luck.
Posts.Title: New lump, here we go again Lavender250 Linda-n3

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2011 06:28PM - edited Aug 15, 2011 06:29PM by Lavender250 Would they make it urgent even for someone without insurance? That was my worry. She seemed to be wearing dollar sign glasses during my whole exam. Would she have insisted on a biopsy if it seemed really urgent? It's weird. She couldn't tell me what it is. She couldn't tell me why it felt benign. She couldn't rule out cancer. So why tell me to wait just because of insurance? Seemed like a very greedy doctor to me which was troubling since they knew I was uninsured when I made the appointment.
Posts.Title: New lump, here we go again Lavender250 Linda-n3

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2011 04:46PM Lavender250 wrote: I feel like such a coward for not being able to keep myself together. But most women even my age check their breasts and see a doctor once a year. I'll always have regrets about not taking care of myself and a cancer diagnosis would only intensify that. I appreciate so much that you guys are here to talk to. I'm so scared of losing my future!
Posts.Title: New lump, here we go again Lavender250 Linda-n3

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2011 01:52PM Lavender250 wrote: I'm doing the blame game on myself too and people are finally getting me to stop doing that. I'm 27 but this applies at any age. Breast cancer can be genetic or random and most of us don't truly see it coming even when it comes. I want to see a cure for  cancer so badly!!! I'm so sick of all the new cases each year and I'm also sick of the sheer TERROR it causes in people's lives... even those with benign conditions. That being said, getting a mammogram is the right thing. I'm going for a biopsy in a little over two weeks. Terrified beyond description but I'm praying that you and I both get GOOD news!
Posts.Title: I think it's going to be bad news etherize cimo37

Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2011 01:17PM Lavender250 wrote: I'm so sorry you are going through this. Something very similar is happening to me only the doctors are making me wait two weeks for an ultrasound. My lumps is very long and painful. It's very good that they are taking you so seriously and booking your tests so quickly. That's definitely something I would like to have. I had an ultrasound on my other breast a week or so ago which was "non-concerning" but I had to wait 1.5 weeks for that. This waiting game is torturing me so I know exactly what you are going through. I'll keeo you in my thoughts and hope for a benign diagnosis! I know you are scared and trust me... you are definitely not alone. It feels like it in our real lives but this group is great.
Posts.Title: scared and worried like never before... scaredmommyof6 SarahsMom

I'm scheduled to have a biopsy on friday and I honeslty can't promise that I won't chicken out. Although there are some people in my life that might force me. How long did you blow off the armpit lump before seeing the doc? I wish I could tell you how to ease the anxiety but I'm trying to figure that out myself. My heart goes out to you and we will all be hoping for good news!
Posts.Title: Biopsy Tomorrow JackieD JackieD

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2011 08:20AM Lavender250 wrote: Hi Jess, I'm wondering the same thing. I have a blue vein over what allegedly was my "cyst" on the left breast. It looked unlike any other blue vein on my breast or body. I asked my PCP and she said it was not a concern but I have also read that it could be caused by cancer. Mine on my left side is not your garden variety vein that you would see anywhere else on the body. It's darker blue, has a more narrow shape and runs right over my "cyst". I'm not sure what to make of it. Apparently my "cyst" had "no solid component" or "internal flow" which is what a vein would cause. Right? I'm hoping someone will know the answer. It's not a "typical" breast cancer symptom. Their explanation is that a malignancy needs blood flow so a vein will appear. If there's no blood flow in your lump, does that mean you are fine? It's confusing. On the other hand, having light blue surface veins on both breasts is very normal. Many women have that especially if they have visible veins on other body parts (i.e., legs). Pale women tend to have visible veins or may develop varicose veins later in life. I'm still worried about my vein but I try to comfort myself with the fact that my ultrasound did not find a worrisome mass in that area. Veins are weird anyway. They can show up in the weirdest places. My cousin has them on her face. Not gross veins but light visible ones.
